## Selected projects in data science, machine learning, scheduling and operations research

---

### Predicting product returns
This project analyzes an online retailer's data using Python to create a classifier that predicts whether an item will be returned. The dataset is from the Data Mining Cup 2014, and models such as Neural Network, XGBoost, CatBoost, and LightGBM are used to make predictions. The top-performing model was CatBoost (GPU) with an MAE of 0.2974 on the test set, placing the solution in the top 4 of the Data Mining Cup 2014 ranking.

![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)  ![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Jupyter-white?logo=Jupyter) 
![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Pandas-white?logo=data:image/png;base64,)

[View code on Github](https://github.com/teodor-georgiev/Online-Retailer-Analysis-2014)

---

### Brand perception dashboard
As part of my master's thesis, I created an interactive web-based dashboard using Dash and Plotly. The primary purpose of the dashboard was to display how consumers perceive different brands.

The first section visualizes the findings from a research paper published in Marketing Science called ["Mining Brand Perceptions from Twitter Social Networks"](http://dx.doi.org/10.1287/mksc.2015.0968), written by Aron Culotta and Jennifer Cutler in 2016.

The second section displays the impact of brand perceptions on the stock market for five well-known brands, including Apple, Coca-Cola, H&M, Nike, and Starbucks. The data used for the visualization was obtained from the social networks Twitter and StockTwits, as well as the marketing research company YouGov.


<img src="images/mobility.png?raw=true" />

### Simulated Annealing algorithm for the Vehicle Routing Problem
Implementation of the Simulated Annealing metaheurstic to solve the Vehicle Routing Problem.

![](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-white?logo=Python)
